name: Muscle
description: An old-school mechanic who values tradition, hard work, and proving yourself

main.title: Old School Rules
main.description: Earn the respect of a veteran who's seen it all

chapters.title: The Proving Ground
chapters.summary: Muscle tests whether you have what it takes

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Techie sent you, huh?

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: That kid's smart, but he overthinks everything. All that data and computers...

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: In my day, you tuned by ear and feel. And we made power. Real power.

choices.text: There's value in both approaches. Technology helps, but nothing replaces experience.
The old ways still work. Some things don't need computers.
Data makes everything easier though.

disappointed_response.speaker: muscle
disappointed_response.text: Easier isn't better, kid. Easy is how you stay mediocre.

disappointed_response.speaker: muscle
disappointed_response.text: Come back when you understand that.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Alright. I can work with that.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Name's... well, people call me Muscle. Been turning wrenches for forty years.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Started in my old man's shop. Built my first engine at sixteen.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: What about you? When'd you first get your hands dirty?

choices.text: Young. Helped my dad work on the family car. That's where the bug bit me.
I'm newer to this, but I'm committed. Learning every day.
Bought my first project car a couple years ago.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Family tradition. I respect that.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: My old man taught me everything. Patience. Precision. Pride in your work.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: He's gone now, but every time I rebuild an engine, I hear his voice.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: 'Measure twice, cut once. And if you're gonna do it, do it right.'

choices.text: That's a good philosophy. I try to live by it too.
Sounds like he was a good teacher.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Look, I'm gonna be straight with you.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: I deal with serious hardware. Forged internals. Racing cams. Stuff that can make or break an engine.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: I need to know you're not gonna cut corners. Tell me - your project car needs new rod bearings. What do you do?

choices.text: Pull the engine, inspect the crank, measure the journals, order bearings to spec, and plasti-gauge clearances on assembly.
Drop the pan and replace the bearings in the car. Faster that way.
Take it to a machine shop and have them do it.

shortcut_response.speaker: muscle
shortcut_response.text: And when that crank is scored because you didn't check it? When those bearings spin because the clearance was wrong?

shortcut_response.speaker: muscle
shortcut_response.text: Shortcuts cost more in the long run. Always.

shortcut_response.speaker: muscle
shortcut_response.text: Come back when you're ready to do things right.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: *nods slowly*

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: That's the right answer. The only answer.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: You can't rush precision work. The engine doesn't care about your schedule.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Alright, kid. You've got potential. Let's see what you can do.

choices.text: I won't let you down.
Looking forward to learning from you.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: I've got some quality rotating assembly parts. Forged pistons, H-beam rods. The good stuff.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: When you're ready to build something serious, come talk to me.

chapters.title: War Stories
chapters.summary: Muscle shares stories from his racing days

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: You ever race, kid?

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Not this modern stuff with traction control and ABS. Real racing. Just you, the car, and the road.

choices.text: A few times. Nothing serious, but I understand the appeal.
Not yet. But I'm building towards it.
Racing seems dangerous.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Back in '84, I was running a Moonhawk with a stroked 440. Built it myself.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: That thing was a monster. Ran 10.8 in the quarter on street tires.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: We'd hit the back roads every Friday night. Twenty, thirty cars sometimes.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: No prize money. No trophies. Just respect.

choices.text: That's what it should be about. The love of the sport.
What happened to the Moonhawk?

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: *long pause*

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Lost it. In '91.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Wife got sick. Hospital bills. Had to sell the car to pay for treatment.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: She didn't make it. And neither did my Moonhawk.

choices.text: I'm sorry. That's a hell of a loss on both counts.
You did the right thing. Family comes first.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Yeah. It was.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Took me years to touch a wrench again after that. Didn't see the point.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: But eventually... cars called me back. It's in my blood. Can't escape it.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Now I help other people build their dreams. It's not the same, but it's something.

choices.text: Maybe someday you'll find another Moonhawk.
Passing on knowledge is the best legacy.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Maybe. We'll see.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Come with me. I want to show you something.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: In the back of my shop, under the tarp.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: It's a '71 Moonhawk. Same year as my old one.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Found it in a barn three years ago. Rust bucket. But the bones are good.

choices.text: You're rebuilding it. Starting over.
That's incredible. Can I see it?

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: This is my last build, kid.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Hands aren't what they used to be. Eyes either. I've got maybe a few more years of turning wrenches left.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: I'm putting everything into this car. Every trick I've learned in forty years.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: And when it's done... I'm gonna take it to the track. One last run.

choices.text: I'd be honored to help if you need an extra pair of hands.
When it's ready, I want to be there to see that run.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: *gruff smile*

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: You know what, kid? I might just take you up on that.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Not many people left who appreciate doing things the right way.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: You remind me of myself. Back when I still had something to prove.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Tell you what. You help me with the Moonhawk, and I'll make sure you have access to everything I've got.

choices.text: It would be an honor to learn from you.
Let's build something legendary.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: That's the spirit.

exchanges.speaker: muscle
exchanges.text: Now let's get to work.

confrontations.text: Saw a kid at the shop today. Wanted me to install Chinese knockoff rod bolts in his engine. 'They're rated the same,' he said. What would you have told him?

responses.text: Walk away. Those bolts fail under stress. It's not worth the risk.
Depends on the application. Street car might be okay.
Quality fasteners are the foundation of any build. No compromise.

unknown.text: You ever rebuild an engine from the ground up?

responses.text: Yes. More than one. It's the best way to learn.
Not yet, but I'm planning to.
No, I usually pay someone else to do it.
